awd_titl_txt: Conference on Special Metrics in Complex Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The Conference on Special Metrics in Complex Geometry will be held at Florida International University from January 7-10, 2021. Complex manifolds are higher-dimensional surfaces that are defined using the complex numbers. Recently, there has been significant progress in the study of "metrics" on complex manifolds, objects that endow these spaces with a shape or more precisely, curvature. The study of these metrics lies at the nexus of complex geometry and geometric analysis. The aim of this conference is to gather together experts working in these two fields to discuss these new and exciting developments. Even though lately there have been many conferences in complex geometry, none have really been organised to address these recent discoveries. This conference serves to fulfill this necessity. In doing so, it will promote collaboration across many areas of the aforementioned fields of complex geometry and geometric analysis. The latest breakthroughs in these two fields will be presented to a new generation of mathematicians, with a particular emphasis on women and those from minority groups. The conference will provide a forum for senior mathematicians to interact with graduate students through the organisation of an optional poster presentation for graduate students which will take place in a non-intimidating and relaxed environment. Ample opportunity will also be provided to women speakers to present their research, with at least one talk per day scheduled for a female speaker. Moreover, the conference will provide a platform for postdocs and junior researchers to present their work. Participants will be brought up-to-date with all of the current developments in the field and will be presented with new avenues of research in the enticing environment that Miami provides in the Winter.
 
More specifically, the Conference on Special Metrics in Complex Geometry will concentrate on the interplay between complex geometry and geometric analysis, with an emphasis being given to equations arising in the construction of hermitian and Kahler metrics with prescribed curvature properties, for example, the complex Monge-Ampere equation in Kahler geometry. These equations are among the most important appearing in geometric analysis and understanding their structure and the techniques involved in their solution are paramount for further progress in the field. Recent breakthroughs include, among others, the independent construction of non-flat Ricci-flat Kahler metrics with maximal volume growth on complex affine space of dimensions three and greater by Li, Conlon-Rochon, and Szekelyhidi, the construction of new examples of gradient expanding and steady Kahler-Ricci solitons by Conlon-Deruelle and Biquard-Macbeth respectively, the solution by Chen-Cheng of a major conjecture of Tian stating the equivalence between the existence of constant scalar curvature Kahler metrics on a compact Kahler manifold and the properness of Mabuchi's K-energy, and the recent families of Ricci-flat Kahler metrics exhibited by Hein-Sun-Viaclovsky-Zhang on K3 surfaces which collapse to an interval with Tian-Yau and Taub-NUT metrics occurring as bubbles. These topics will all form part of the conversation at the conference in January 2021.  More details will be available at http://faculty.fiu.edu/~rconlon/conference.htm

por.por_cntn:
Summary:

The Special Metrics in Complex Geometry conference was held at UT Dallas from May 16 through 20, 2022, inclusive, and was organised by Ronan Conlon (UT Dallas), Hans-Joachim Hein (Muenster), Song Sun (UC Berkeley), and Gabor Szekelyhidi (Northwestern). The webpage for the conference may be found here:

https://sites.google.com/view/smcg2022/home.

Speakers:

The conference had 22 speakers in total, namely:

Ethan Addison (Notre Dame)

Michael Albanese (UQAM)

Vestislav Apostolov (Nantes/UQAM)

Martin de Borbon (King's College London)

Jingrui Cheng (Stony Brook)

Charles Cifarelli (Nantes)

Mary Cook (U. of Rochester)

Tamas Darvas (U.of Maryland)

Eleonora Di Nezza (Ecole Polytechnique)

Xin Fu (UC Irvine)

Claude LeBrun (Stony Brook)

Mehdi Lejmi (CUNY)

Hongyi Liu (UC Berkeley)

Heather Macbeth (Fordham U.)

Sean Paul (U. of Wisconsin-Madison)

Frederic Rochon (UQAM)

Bianca Santoro (CUNY/Muenster)

Jian Song (Rutgers)

Freid Tong (Harvard)

Jeff Viaclovsky (UC Irvine)

Chuwen Wang (Columbia U.)

Qi Yao (Muenster)

Outcomes:

The conference provided a platform for young researchers and under-represented minorities to present their work. Indeed, 10 of the 22 speakers, nearly half, were graduate students or postdocs and 5 of the 22 speakers, nearly one quarter, were from under-represented groups. We were able to fully support 3 student participants from under-represented groups and provide partial support for a further 8 young researchers.

One thing that was unique about this conference was that there was a panel discussion led by Bianca Santoro where several speakers from under-represented groups in mathematics shared their experiences studying mathematics and working in the field. The audience contributed much to this discussion with feedback and questions about the experiences shared.

Participants:

The conference was attended by 45 participants in total. Student participants came from all parts of the country and internationally, with many student participants coming from schools in California, Maryland, Michigan, and Tennessee, as well as the UK. Numerous participants and almost all of the speakers expressed particular gratitude for the fact that this conference was the first in-person conference they had attended since before the pandemic.

Conclusion:

The Special Metrics in Complex Geometry conference was a major international geometry conference, drawing participants from all over the country and abroad. The talks were comprehensible and at a very high level (as judged by both the organisers and by all received feedback). Products from the conference include fostering new research, new collaborations, and the dissemination of mathematical knowledge. Slides from the talks are accessible on the conference webpage.
